climbs.name: Longs Lies
climbs.fa: Tyler Phillips, Pete VanSlooten, Nate Williams, Tyler McConvill  4/06

content.description:
P1. Start up the very cool looking cracks using the big patina's for holds until you reach a 2 bolt anchor at 100 feet. 5.9

P2.From big stance climb up and right. Climb up the obvious sweet finger crack. 5.9+ 50 feet

P3 Bring some nuts or cable swages for tying off BOMBER (as of 4/06;) ) bolts to the window,climb through the window onto terra-firma and a 2 bolt belay. this pitch might be freeable? A0. 40 feet

It is possible to combine 2 and 3.
content.protection: Doubles on everything #1 metolius to #4 camalot. Slings very helpful, maybe some eiters for the aid.
content.location:
This route lies about 600 yards north from the tourist slot canyon. There is a sign in spring posted that climbing beyond this point is illegal due to Peregrine Falcons. Look for the obvious window up high on the formation

2 double rope raps get you back down. Replacement slings for rap stations might be nice.

content.description: The crux come at 3/4 height, it involves leaving the crack and going hand traversing. On the FA I pounded a #2 angle in at the crux, I went back 2 years later and pulled it out with my finger (it even had a bail biner on it!!) Now a nice TCU fits in there. Its a GREAT "just got here, need to warm up" route.
content.protection: #1 metolius to #3 camalot, maybe a sling. Replacement slings for the anchor might be nice.
content.location: When you are driving down the Burr Trail there is a large obvious slot canyon on its West side (only one), just across the road are these crack systems.Flipper Babies is the left hand crack of the two similar looking side by side crack systems. Take 10 steps from you car.

content.description:
A journey through crack sizes from squeeze to fingers.  The 70 degree angle of the slab keeps the grade mellow.  The crux is the crescendo finger crack (30 feet of #0.3 Camalots).   Spacious belay ledge.

You will need a #2 and #3 Camalot for the belay (the gear for the belay is low to the ground and about 10 feet back from the edge).  Extra webbing might be useful.  No anchors, no walk-off.  A single rope (60m) rappel from my abandoned gear puts you on the ground with rope stretch.
content.protection: Double-rack of Camalots (#4 and down). Bring an extra #2 and #3 for the belay.
content.location: 4.6 miles down-canyon from Lower Gulch Trailhead.  Right-side.  Tan slab with obvious thin crack (if the lighting is right).  The slab is not on the main cliff; it is a perpendicular outcropping that faces up-canyon.

climbs.name: Cactus Fall
climbs.fa: Mike Baker, Shar Baker, Wilson Goodrich  May 31, 2000

content.description: Start from the right moving up a ledge where the off-width crack starts.  There is a small crack inside the o.w. that fits smaller pro (~0.75) that saves the wider stuff for up higher where you need it.  Crux at the o.w. bulge.  Original description in BjørnStad's Desert Rock IV.
content.protection: Standard Rack to BD #4.  Two #4s recommended.  Two fixed pins at the anchor
content.location: Park 1/2 mile from The Gulch TH at the concrete culvert.  Follow trail on east side of the stream through the log cattle fence.  Cross stream after another few hundred yards.  The location is on the west side of the Gulch, 150 feet right of 5.8 Corner.

content.description: This silly route starts on the west side of a boulder that looks like a "summit" when viewed from the right spot.
content.protection:
3 QD's, Rap from 2 bolts.

Replacement slings might be nice for the top.
content.location: From Longs Lies look south (same side as Longs Lies)there is a talus/boulderfield. It is the biggest boulder in there, it looks like a sport route could be bolted up the front (facing the road). But the Beam(Jim)Bump climbs up the back. Copious amounts of Jim Beam will help.

content.description: This spicy meatball is just right of Flipper babies. Hard/weird crack moves at the bottom turn into cruising past one drilled pin and up to 2 more drilled angles on the vertical crux, throw a dynmaic sideways thingy towards the anchor, "that edge IS as good as it looks" whewww..
content.protection:
Qd's, slings, #1 metolius to #4 camalot.

Replacement slings for the anchor might be nice.
content.location: The route is to the right of Flipper Babies. Take 14 steps from your car. ;)

climbs.name: 5.8 Corner
climbs.fa: FA unknown.   FRA Mike Baker, Shar Baker, Wilson Goodrich, May 1999

content.description:
A fun left-facing corner on the west side of The Gulch.  Jam and lieback to glory.

Gets direct AM sun.  This part of the canyon is not in the raptor closure area.

This route is described in Bjornstad's 'Desert Rock IV' (2003:410-411).
content.protection:
Standard/light trad rack of single nuts & cams to ~ #3 C4.

Two drilled pins provide the rap anchor, with slings and a pair of opposed crabs.
content.location:
This crack is in The Gulch proper, not in Long Canyon (which is actually a tributary to The Gulch). When driving the Burr Trail from Boulder, at ~10.1 miles you will be dropping into the canyon, and you come to a BLM trailhead for The Gulch.

Don't use this trailhead, but keep driving ca. 1/2 mile east up the bottom of the canyon to the little concrete bridge/culvert where the stream of The Gulch crosses the Burr Trail.

Park here and walk north up the east side of the stream. Pass the log fence across the canyon bottom, and another 2-3 minutes easy walking will bring you to the climb, which is across the stream to the west.
